title: NO TILL VS. THE PAPERPOT TRANSPLANTER

tasks.task: Buying and troubleshooting a Paper Pot Transplanter for a no-till, deep compost mulch market garden.
subtasks: Purchasing the Paper Pot Transplanter system three years ago.
First unsuccessful attempt at using the Paper Pot Transplanter with beets, leading to plant damage.
Seeking advice from a friend (Paul) on proper use of the Paper Pot Transplanter.

tasks.task: Preparing seedlings for transplantation using the Paper Pot Transplanter.
subtasks: Hardening off seedlings by leaving them outdoors for two weeks before transplantation.
Saturating Paper Pot Trays with water before planting to prevent ripping during insertion.
Using a cookie sheet to bottom-water Paper Pot Trays for optimal moisture content.

tasks.task: Bed preparation for Paper Pot Transplanting.
subtasks: Clearing previous crop residues and straightening bed lines with string.
Applying compost to beds planned for Paper Pot Transplanting.
Using a tilther (e.g., NeverSink Iconoclast) to blend compost with topsoil without tilling.
Raking and smoothing the compost layer to create a raised planting bed.
Ensuring proper bed aeration with a broad fork to facilitate root penetration into native soil.

tasks.task: Transplanting seedlings with the Paper Pot Transplanter.
subtasks: Adjusting the Paper Pot Transplanter settings for optimal depth and root coverage.
Dealing with overgrown seedlings by tearing them apart and stage planting to prevent issues.
Transplanting specific crops (e.g., Salanova lettuce, tomatoes) using the Paper Pot Transplanter.

tasks.task: Addressing challenges with using Paper Pot Transplanter after certain crops.
subtasks: Avoiding the use of Paper Pot Transplanter on beds with residual root systems (e.g., cilantro).
Considering crop rotation to efficiently use Paper Pot Transplanter on root-free beds (e.g., after carrots).
